awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Optimal Sensor Selection and Robust Traffic Detection and Estimation in a World of Connected Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
Reliable traffic management strategies require accurate knowledge of traffic levels on roads. Though the emergence of connected vehicles (CV) offers tremendous potential for sharing traffic data about vehicles' locations and speeds through wireless communications, there are both privacy concerns and bandwidth constraints - not all users want to share and not all vehicles are able to share. This project will address both issues by designing methods to guide the selection of some road users for data sharing and analysis to provide accurate estimation of traffic levels in real time, while addressing privacy and bandwidth issues. Throughout this project, training modules in  traffic and machine learning sciences will be designed at both UT San Antonio and UT Austin and students from underrepresented groups will be recruited at UTSA where 58 percent of enrolled students are minorities.

The project will: (i) consider privacy of user data hence maintaining anonymity of vehicles and users, (ii) identify sudden changes in traffic conditions due to accidents, (iii) design a time-varying selection of traffic data collected in real-time from CVs, and (iv) quantify limits on the network bandwidth and uncertainty in traffic conditions and road properties. The project's major contribution lies in advancing the use of CVs as real-time, mobile traffic sensors. This involves the integration of concepts from multiple disciplines: traffic flow, networked systems, estimation, and machine learning theories. Specifically, the project will investigate computationally scalable methods that traffic operators can utilize to optimally sample data from CVs while satisfying privacy and bandwidth constraints, thereby monitoring traffic in real-time. The theoretical foundations will be validated with realistic traffic setups through collaborations with the cities of Austin and San Antonio. The broader impact of the research transcends traffic networks: the computational algorithms will be applicable to related problems involving networked systems of partial differential equations and moving sensing platforms such as environmental monitoring by robot and unmanned aerial vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With ever growing population centers, traffic congestion has become a major issue in most areas of the world. One of the most inexpensive ways to address traffic congestion is through better traffic control mechanisms such as dynamic speed limits, dynamic tolling or demand response. However, the performance of traffic control methods heavily depend on the ability for us to obtain accurate traffic maps (estimates): controlling traffic using incorrect traffic estimates could potentially make the situation worse.

With the emergence of Connected Vehicles (CVs), we now have more and more traffic data. However, not all of this traffic data can be used, and there are practical limitations on the bandwidth of communication networks, that limit the amount of data that can be sent out. Furthermore, this data can pose privacy problems.

In this proposal, we focus on the following question: How can traffic operators optimally obtain data from existing traffic flow sensors and CVs while satisfying privacy and bandwidth constraints, thereby monitoring traffic in real time, which high accuracy, low cost, and low potential privacy intrusion.

 To address this research question, we leverage the classical Cell Transmission Model (CTM) that describes the evolution of traffic density and flux in transportation networks. This model forms a nonlinear dynamic network modeling traffic flow---a network model that explicitly incorporates uncertainty due to natural or man-made adversities, as a result of traffic networks becoming
highly reliant on wireless communications.

More specifically, we have investigated the following problems:

1. The fixed and time-varying placement/selection of different types of traffic sensors and CVs.
2. The problem of real-time detection of highway congestion mode changes through new machine learning algorithms.
3.The problem of robust traffic estimation: how can we build a state estimation algorithm that works even with high level of model errors, caused by road closures, erroneous traffic data/sensor faults, or potential cyber-attacks.

These problems have been solved using a combination of novel control systems methods and hybrid control systems/machine learning algorithms. The resulting work led to more than 10 publications in international journals and conferences. In particular, this research led to novel algorithms and methods for solving the problems of traffic state estimation using advanced flow models (second order models), and methods for optimally placing new traffic sensors on the road network.

The impact of this research transcends traffic networks: solving these problems gives new insights on how to solve other critical sustainability problems, such as flood monitoring using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), which has similar dynamic sensor placement and estimation aspects
